candidate_info.name: Measha Brueggergosman
candidate_info.background: Measha Brueggergosman (born Gosman; June 28, 1977) is a Canadian soprano from Fredericton, New Brunswick. She has performed internationally as a world-renowned opera singer and concert artist, winning numerous awards and recognition.
candidate_info.cultural_context: Brueggergosman is celebrated for her contributions to the world of opera and classical music, representing Afro-Canadian talent on global stages. Her performances often celebrate Black culture and music, including spirituals.

candidate_info.name: Anna Minerva Henderson
candidate_info.background: Anna Minerva Henderson (August 8, 1887 – 1987) was a poet, teacher, and civil servant from Saint John, New Brunswick. She was known for her contributions to literature as one of the first Black Canadian women poets.
candidate_info.cultural_context: Henderson is recognized for her pioneering work in Canadian literature and for advocating for the representation of Black voices in literature, paving the way for future generations of writers.

candidate_info.name: Abraham Beverley Walker
candidate_info.background: Abraham Beverley Walker (1861 - 1947) was the first Black lawyer in Canada and fought for the rights of Black Canadians, serving as a role model and pioneer for future generations.
candidate_info.cultural_context: Walker’s legacy is integral to the fight for civil rights and justice for Black Canadians, paving the way for greater representation in Canadian law.

candidate_info.name: Willie O'Ree
candidate_info.background: Willie O'Ree (born October 15, 1935) is a Canadian former professional ice hockey player who is recognized as the first Black player in the National Hockey League (NHL).
candidate_info.cultural_context: O'Ree's entry into the NHL in 1958 broke racial barriers in ice hockey and inspired many young Black athletes to pursue the sport.

candidate_info.name: Robert Henry
candidate_info.background: Robert Henry served as a soldier during WWII and became a community activist fighting for the rights of Black Canadians in new Brunswick.
candidate_info.cultural_context: Henry's activism laid foundational work for later civil rights movements within the province.

candidate_info.name: Lena O'Ree
candidate_info.background: Lena O'Ree was a prominent figure in the New Brunswick community for her work in civil rights and activism, being part of the O'Ree family legacy.
candidate_info.cultural_context: Her contributions are recognized as pivotal in advancing the rights of Afro-Canadians in the area.

candidate_info.name: Frederick Boyd
candidate_info.background: Frederick Boyd was a 20th-century African Canadian who made contributions in various community initiatives within New Brunswick.
candidate_info.cultural_context: His advocacy work and community involvement greatly supported the growth and recognition of the Afro-Canadian culture.

candidate_info.name: Thandiwe McCarthy
candidate_info.background: Thandiwe McCarthy is a contemporary New Brunswick artist and memoirist dedicated to sharing his experiences as a seventh-generation Black New Brunswicker.
candidate_info.cultural_context: His work sheds light on Black history and identity in Canada, providing a modern voice for the ongoing narrative.

candidate_info.name: Stephen Davidson
candidate_info.background: Stephen Davidson is a historian and author focused on Black Loyalist history in New Brunswick, providing essential insights into the lives and experiences of Black individuals in the province.
candidate_info.cultural_context: His research efforts have brought greater recognition to the contributions of Black Loyalists in shaping history.

candidate_info.name: George L. Fontaine
candidate_info.background: George L. Fontaine was a notable entrepreneur and community leader in New Brunswick who significantly contributed to the economic development of the Black community.
candidate_info.cultural_context: His efforts in fostering economic empowerment remain a key part of New Brunswick's Afro-Canadian heritage.

candidate_info.name: Charlotte M. Bell
candidate_info.background: Charlotte M. Bell is recognized for her activism and dedication to promoting education and opportunities for Afro-Canadian youth in New Brunswick.
candidate_info.cultural_context: Her commitment to education has empowered countless individuals, ensuring the legacy of knowledge and awareness within the community.
